newsitem.title: USA: U.S. banks eager to lend to business, Fed says.
newsitem.headline: U.S. banks eager to lend to business, Fed says.

text.p: U.S. banks were more generous toward businesses than consumers in terms of extending credit over the past three months, a Federal Reserve survey issued on Friday showed.
The latest survey of senior loan officers at 59 domestic banks and 24 U.S. branches and agencies of foreign banks showed a trend that began in 1996 toward restricting consumer lending has continued.
"The responses suggest that over the past three months domestic banks have become more accommodative lenders to businesses but have tightened credit to households," it said.

The survey said that stiff competition had caused many banks to offer easier terms for both commercial and industrial and for commercial real estate loans. It said there has been "a slight strengthening" in demand for both types of business credit.
The latest survey updates one done in January and published on February 10.

"Once again, both standards and terms for consumer loans were tightened and banks reported less demand for these loans," it found. Standards for home mortgages were little changed but demand for them weakened a little since January.

The Fed survey said that about half of the banks tightened standards for new credit-card accounts during the past three months and about 20 percent imposed tougher standards for other consumer loans as well.
Some 40 percent of the banks also reduced their credit limits on credit-card lines since January, the Fed found.
While banks were generally more eager to lend to businesses, the Fed noted some differences between domestic banks and the U.S. branches of foreign banks.
It said "small net fractions" of foreign-controlled banks had tightened some terms on commercial loans since January.
"This represents a shift for foreign banks, which reported having eased terms on these loans for the past several surveys," the Fed said.
The banks that tightened their commercial lending rules said they did so because of "lower tolerance for risk and a deterioration in their current or expected capital position," the survey reported.

But the larger percentage of banks that went the other route -- making it easier for businesses to get loans -- said their motivation was more aggressive competition from other banks and from nonbank sources of credit.
